vectorData.altText:
The hip bone is formed from three bones that are separate, but joined by cartilage, at birth; they fuse with physical maturity. These are the ilium, ischium and pubis.
The hip bones articulate with the sacrum at the sacroiliac joint.
The sacroiliac joint is a synovial joint, reinforced by massive ligaments, the interosseous sacroiliac ligament, and the anterior and posterior sacroiliac ligaments. 
The two hip bones articulate anteriorly at the pubic symphysis.
The symphyseal surfaces of the pubic bones are covered by articular cartilage and are joined by a fibrocartilagenous disc, much like an intervertebral disc. The joint is reinforced by superior and inferior pubic ligaments.
The pelvis is formed by four bones, the two ossa     coxae      (hip bones), the sacrum and the coccyx.
